variant.question: The following problems may occur when starting a twin-spool turbofan engine

options.text: no N1 rotation, although N2 may accelerate normally.
no N2 rotation, although N1 may accelerate normally.
a hung (abortive) start with no light-up indication after `fuel-on` selection.
a hung (abortive) start with fuel flow indication zero after `fuel-on` selection.

variant.question: What are the possible causes of a hot start, and what are the indications of one? A hot start can be caused by

options.text: an early starter cut-out, fuel mis-scheduling, or strong tailwinds. The engine may spend a considerable time at very low RPM (sub-idle) but should continue to accelerate, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.

high outside air temperature, fuel mis-scheduling, or high starter motor RPM. The engine may spend a considerable time at very high RPM but stops accelerating, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.
a late starter cut-out, insufficient fuel supply, or strong headwinds. The engine will accelerate to flight idle RPM and the turbine temperatures may appear low.

an early starter cut-out, fuel mis-scheduling, or strong tailwinds. The engine may spend a considerable time at very low RPM (sub-idle) and stops accelerating, the turbine temperatures may appear high or exceed the limitations.

variant.question: What are the possible causes and indications of a tailpipe fire?

options.text: Fuel may puddle in the turbine casings and exhaust during start-up or shutdown, and then ignite. This can result in a highly visible jet of flame out of the back of the engine.
Fuel may puddle in the turbine casings and exhaust during start-up or shutdown, and then ignite. On the flight deck, an engine fire warning is generated.
Fuel mis-scheduling or strong tailwinds can cause fuel ignition in the tailpipe. The turbine temperature increases above the certified limit.
Fuel may puddle in the turbine casings and exhaust during start-up or shutdown, and then ignite. However, the EGT remains unchanged.

variant.question:
After experiencing a loud bang, you notice a master caution annunciator and a large yawing moment to the right, that you correct by pressing the left rudder. As the pilot flying in this twin engine jet aircraft, you ask the pilot monitoring to "State the malfunction" and thereafter you get the following reply:
"Nr. 2 engine - no N1 rotation, high EGT, no N2 rotation, no fuel flow, high oil temperature, low oil pressure, high vibration".
What has most likely happened?

options.text: You have ingested FOD into your right engine.
You have had a rapid decompression and the loud bang was from a bursting cockpit window.
You are experiencing a right engine stall.
A tyre on the main wheel has burst and you are skidding off the runway.

variant.question: With regard to a twin spool gas turbine engine, an abortive start (hung start) will result in:

options.text: N2 speed stabilising at a lower than normal rpm and a subsequent increase in EGT.
N2 speed stabilising at a higher than normal rpm and a subsequent increase in EGT.
N2 speed stabilising at a lower than normal rpm and a subsequent decrease in EGT.
N2 speed stabilising at a higher than normal rpm and a subsequent decrease in EGT.

variant.question: A hung (abortive) start of a gas turbine engine may be caused by:

options.text: a too low pneumatic starter pressure.
failure of the fuel to ignite in the starting sequence after the engine has been accelerated to the required rpm by the starter.
compressor surging.
the starter cutting out early in the starting sequence before the engine has accelerated to the required rpm for ignition.

variant.question:
After experiencing a loud bang, a master caution annunciator and a large yawing moment to the right which you correct by pushing left rudder.  The Pilot Flying in a twin engine jet aircraft asks the Pilot Monitoring to "State the malfunction" and get the following reply; "Number 2 Engine" "NO N1 Rotation" "NO N2 Rotation" "NO Fuel Flow" "High EGT" "High Oil TEMP" "LOW Oil Pressure" "High Vibration".  
 What has most likely happened?

options.text: The aircraft has ingested F.O.D in to the right engine.
The aircraft suffered a rapid decompression and the loud bang was from a cockpit window bursting.
A tyre on the main wheel has bursted and the aircraft is skidding off the runway.
The aircraft is experiencing a right engine stall.

variant.question: An abortive (hung) start is the term used to describe an attempt to start in which the engine:

options.text: lights up, but fails to accelerate sufficiently.
commences initial rotation, but fails to receive any fuel.
fails to light up.
will not rotate.
